channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Portable muon beam could accelerate archaeology scans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03245-8

Laser plasma device could be light enough to be used on the field.
item.dc:title: Portable muon beam could accelerate archaeology scans

item.title: A ductile chromium–molybdenum alloy resistant to high-temperature oxidation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09516-8

A single-phase chromium–molybdenum–silicon alloy is described that exhibits compression ductility at room temperature as well as resistance to oxidation, pesting, nitridation and scale spallation at temperatures up to at least 1,100 °C.
item.dc:title: A ductile chromium–molybdenum alloy resistant to high-temperature oxidation
item.dc:creator: Frauke Hinrichs
Georg Winkens
Lena Katharina Kramer
Gabriely Falcão
Ewa M. Hahn
Daniel Schliephake
Michael Konrad Eusterholz
Sandipan Sen
Mathias Christian Galetz
Haruyuki Inui
Alexander Kauffmann
Martin Heilmaier

item.title: Quantum-amplified global-phase spectroscopy on an optical clock transition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09578-8

The precision of determining the phase of an optical atomic clock is increased above the standard quantum limit in a new spectroscopic method.
item.dc:title: Quantum-amplified global-phase spectroscopy on an optical clock transition
item.dc:creator: Leon Zaporski
Qi Liu
Gustavo Velez
Matthew Radzihovsky
Zeyang Li
Simone Colombo
Edwin Pedrozo-Peñafiel
Vladan Vuletić

item.title: Programmable on-chip nonlinear photonics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09620-9

An optical slab waveguide with highly programmable nonlinear functionality is described, enabling the demonstration of versatile control over broadband second-harmonic generation across the spectral, spatial and spatio-spectral domains.
item.dc:title: Programmable on-chip nonlinear photonics
item.dc:creator: Ryotatsu Yanagimoto
Benjamin A. Ash
Mandar M. Sohoni
Martin M. Stein
Yiqi Zhao
Federico Presutti
Marc Jankowski
Logan G. Wright
Tatsuhiro Onodera
Peter L. McMahon

item.title: A quantum boost for ultra-precise clocks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03235-w

The light frequency associated with changes in the energy state of atoms can be used to define the ticking of high-precision optical clocks. Experiments with ytterbium atoms have further enhanced the clocks’ precision by using a quantum amplification technique.
item.dc:title: A quantum boost for ultra-precise clocks

item.title: Sacrificial metal speeds up synthesis of nano-alloys from multiple elements
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02973-1

An approach for making nanoscale high-entropy alloys using liquid metal provides much-needed control over the structure and composition of these remarkable materials.
item.dc:title: Sacrificial metal speeds up synthesis of nano-alloys from multiple elements
item.dc:creator: Yunqing Kang
Yusuke Yamauchi

item.title: Groundbreaking quantum-tunnelling experiments win physics Nobel
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03194-2

John Clarke, Michel Devoret and John Martinis discovered quantum physics on a macroscopic scale, paving the way for quantum computing.
item.dc:title: Groundbreaking quantum-tunnelling experiments win physics Nobel
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Gibney
Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Daily briefing: Physics Nobel for quantum tunnelling on a macroscopic scale
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03292-1

Three researchers share this year’s Nobel Prize in Physics for demonstrating that quantum tunnelling could be observed in a special type of circuit. Plus, neurons can pass messages through tiny tubes and what a doughnut can tell us about the path to true prosperity.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Physics Nobel for quantum tunnelling on a macroscopic scale
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham
